metadata.title: EHR System Test Scenario - Progressive Revelation
metadata.description: Test scenario demonstrating progressive EHR data revelation
learning_objectives: Recognize when to review patient in person

state_change_rules.clinical_manifestation: Patient has increased work of breathing, O2 sats dropped to 88%
state_change_rules.notification_message: Nurse calling: Margaret Thompson is more breathless

state_change_rules.clinical_manifestation: Registrar reviewed, started NIV, patient improving
Patient increasingly drowsy, CO2 retention suspected

stable_with_concerns.observations: RR 22, SpO2 92% on 2L/min via NC, HR 92, BP 145/88, T 36.8°C
stable_with_concerns.in_person_note: EHR reviewed. Admitted this morning with 3-day history of increased SOB and productive cough. Known COPD GOLD 3. Penicillin allergy noted. Currently on ward with low-level O2 requirement. Nurse concerned about increased work of breathing and dropping saturations over past hour. Patient reports feeling more breathless than earlier today.
stable_with_concerns.in_person_examination:
Alert, sitting upright in bed, speaking in full sentences but appears mildly dyspnoeic
Obs: RR 22, SpO2 92% on 2L/min via NC, HR 92, BP 145/88, T 36.8°C
Resp: Using accessory muscles. Reduced air entry bilateral bases, scattered wheeze throughout. Percussion resonant
CVS: HS I + II, no murmurs. Peripheral pulses present, CRT <2s
Abdo: Soft, non-tender, no organomegaly
Neuro: GCS 15/15, PEARL

nursing_impression.general_appearance: Patient looks a bit breathless but is managing to speak in full sentences. She's sitting upright and alert.
nursing_impression.concerns: I'm a bit worried about her breathing - it's faster than usual and she's using her shoulders more. Her oxygen saturations have been dropping slightly over the last hour.
nursing_impression.recent_events: She's had two nebulizers in the last 3 hours which helped a little. She managed to eat half her dinner about an hour ago.
nursing_impression.mental_state: She's alert and oriented, seems a bit anxious about her breathing but is cooperative.

deteriorating.observations: RR 28, SpO2 88% on 4L/min via NC, HR 105, BP 152/92, T 37.1°C
deteriorating.in_person_note: Patient has deteriorated significantly in past 30 minutes. Increasing dyspnoea despite further nebulizers. Oxygen requirement increased from 2L to 4L but saturations remain low at 88%. Patient anxious and frightened. Previous admission required NIV for Type 2 respiratory failure (noted in consultant review from 3 months ago).
deteriorating.in_person_examination:
Visibly distressed, speaking only in short phrases, appears exhausted
Obs: RR 28, SpO2 88% on 4L/min via NC, HR 105, BP 152/92, T 37.1°C
Resp: Marked accessory muscle use, pursed lip breathing. Poor air entry bilaterally, widespread wheeze, prolonged expiratory phase
CVS: Tachycardic, regular rhythm. HS I + II. JVP not elevated
Abdo: Soft, non-tender
Neuro: GCS 15/15, appears fatigued. Mild peripheral cyanosis noted

nursing_impression.general_appearance: She looks really unwell now - she's struggling to breathe and can only speak a few words at a time. Her lips look slightly blue.
nursing_impression.concerns: I'm quite worried about her. She's deteriorated significantly in the last half hour despite two more nebulizers. She's exhausting herself with the work of breathing. I think she needs urgent review.
nursing_impression.recent_events: Her saturations dropped from 92% to 88% over about 20 minutes. I've increased her oxygen to 4 litres but she's not improving. She's also becoming more anxious which seems to be making things worse.
nursing_impression.mental_state: She's alert but very anxious and frightened. She keeps saying she can't catch her breath. She's still oriented to time and place.

critically_unwell.observations: RR 32, SpO2 85% on 15L via NRB, HR 115, BP 138/85, T 37.2°C, drowsy and confused
critically_unwell.in_person_note: CRITICAL DETERIORATION. Patient has become drowsy and confused over past 15 minutes. Now GCS 13/15 (was 15/15 earlier). Unable to speak. Breathing pattern abnormal. On 15L via NRB mask but saturations only 85%. Strong suspicion of severe Type 2 respiratory failure with CO2 retention. History of requiring NIV on previous admission. URGENT senior review and respiratory support needed.
critically_unwell.in_person_examination:
Exhausted, drowsy, responding to voice only
Obs: RR 32 (shallow), SpO2 85% on 15L via NRB, HR 115, BP 138/85, T 37.2°C
Resp: Paradoxical breathing pattern. Minimal air entry. Unable to speak
CVS: Tachycardic, weak pulses
Abdo: Unable to assess adequately
Neuro: GCS 13/15 (E3V4M6) - drowsy, confused. PEARL but sluggish response
Central cyanosis present, clammy

nursing_impression.general_appearance: She's in a critical state - she looks exhausted and her breathing pattern is very abnormal. She's drowsy and her color is terrible, lips and tongue are blue.
nursing_impression.concerns: This is an emergency. She's barely responding now - I have to shake her shoulder to get a response. I'm very concerned she's going to stop breathing. We need senior help immediately.
nursing_impression.recent_events: She became drowsier very quickly over the last 10-15 minutes. I've put her on the non-rebreathe mask at 15 litres but it's not helping. She was trying to pull the mask off initially but now she's too drowsy to even do that.
nursing_impression.mental_state: She's drowsy and confused, only opening her eyes when I talk loudly or touch her. When she does respond, she's disorientated and doesn't seem to know where she is. This is a major change from 30 minutes ago.

stable.observations: RR 18, SpO2 95% on 2L/min, HR 82, BP 138/82, T 36.9°C
stable.in_person_note: Patient reviewed following senior escalation. Now on NIV support commenced by registrar approximately 1 hour ago. Marked clinical improvement noted - patient comfortable, speaking normally, good color. Saturations improved to 95%. Patient cooperative with NIV and tolerating well. Continues on treatment for COPD exacerbation.
stable.in_person_examination:
Comfortable at rest, alert and oriented, conversing normally
Obs: RR 18, SpO2 95% on 2L/min, HR 82, BP 138/82, T 36.9°C
Resp: Comfortable breathing, good air entry bilaterally, minimal wheeze
CVS: HS I + II, regular rhythm, normal volume
Abdo: Soft, non-tender
Neuro: GCS 15/15, appropriate responses
Well perfused, warm peripheries

nursing_impression.general_appearance: She looks so much better now - she's comfortable, breathing easily, and has good color. What a difference from earlier!
nursing_impression.concerns: I'm much happier with her now. She's stable and responding well to treatment. I'll keep monitoring her closely but I'm not worried anymore.
nursing_impression.recent_events: Since the registrar started the NIV support about an hour ago, she's improved dramatically. Her breathing has settled right down and her saturations have come up nicely. She's even managed to have a cup of tea.
nursing_impression.mental_state: She's fully alert and oriented now, chatting normally. She's relieved and says she feels much better. She was asking about when she might be able to go home.

ABG.interpretation: Mild Type 2 respiratory failure with compensation

result_data.findings: Hyperinflated lung fields consistent with COPD. No focal consolidation. No pneumothorax.

CXR.interpretation: Changes consistent with known COPD. No acute pathology.

ABG.interpretation: Type 2 respiratory failure with partial compensation

result_data.findings: Hyperinflated lung fields. Possible right lower zone opacity - ? consolidation vs atelectasis.

CXR.interpretation: Possible infective focus right lower zone

ABG.interpretation: Severe Type 2 respiratory failure with acidosis

result_data.findings: Hyperinflated lungs. Right lower zone consolidation. No pneumothorax. Cardiomediastinal contours normal.

CXR.interpretation: Right lower lobe pneumonia on background of COPD

result_data.findings: Hyperinflated lung fields. Resolving right lower zone changes.

initial_request.nurse_concern: Patient more short of breath, could you review?

content.history_presenting_complaint: 3 day history of increasing SOB, productive cough with green sputum. Normally independent for ADLs. No chest pain or haemoptysis.
content.social_history: Lives alone, independent. Ex-smoker (50 pack years), quit 5 years ago.

content.update: Patient seen on evening round. Clinically stable, tolerating oral intake.
content.examination:
Improved air entry, less wheeze 
Continue to observe
Aim discharge tomorrow

content.clinical_note: Patient reports feeling slightly more breathless. Encouraged deep breathing exercises. Will continue to monitor.

content.review: Reviewed patient during previous admission 3 months ago for COPD exacerbation.
content.assessment: Known difficult to manage COPD. Previous admission required NIV support for Type 2 respiratory failure.
content.recommendation: Low threshold for NIV if deteriorates. Avoid high flow oxygen - risk of CO2 retention.

result_data.findings: Hyperinflated lung fields consistent with COPD. No focal consolidation. No pneumothorax.
result_data.conclusion: Changes consistent with known COPD. No acute pathology.

investigation_results.interpretation: Type 2 respiratory failure with partial compensation
